document.masterDocTitle: Predatory midges of the tribes Palpomyiini and Sphaeromiini (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) from the Middle East, with keys and descriptions of new species

subSubSection.paragraph: Entirely blackish brown species, except tarsomeres 1â€“3 pale. Scutellum with 6 large setae. Fore femur with 2â€“4 ventral spines. Male genitalia large; gonocoxite very long and slender, gonostylus short, divided into 3â€“4 tooth-like lobes; aedeagus with slender, very long median process that is nearly straight
on distal portion; parameres fused, expanded on distal portion, with distinct lateral ribs, apex with 2 small processes. Female with 2 ovoid, distinctly unequal seminal capsules.

ISRAEL : 1 â™€ , Sadom, 26 May 1976 , A. Freidberg leg. ( TAU ); 2 â™€â™€ , Berekhat Yaâ€™ar, 6 Jun. 2003 , A. Freidberg leg. ( TAU ); 1 â™€ , Besor Nature Reserve, Tel Sharuhen, 31Âº17â€² N , 34Âº29â€² E , 11 May 2005 , A. Freidberg leg. ( TAU ); 1 â™‚ , Herzliya, swamp, 32Âº10.3â€² N , 34Âº49.4â€² E , 11 May 2008 , A. Freidberg leg. ( TAU ).
LEBANON : 1 â™‚ , Tyre, 33Âº16.232â€² N , 35 Âº12.706â€² E , net, 12 May 2012 , P. Dominiak leg. ( CEIUG ).

In the Middle East and North Africa, the subgenus
Pygobezzia
is represented by two very similar species,
B. albicornis
and
B. fuliginata
. The original description of
B. aegyptia
by Kieffer (1925) , based on a single female, is very poor; however, it matches the description of
B. albicornis
. Unfortunately, the female holotype of
B. aegyptia
was probably not saved by Kieffer. Accordingly, we regard
B. aegyptia
as a new junior synonym of
B. albicornis
, because the latter species is more common in the region and was reported earlier from Egypt by Becker (1903) as Ceratoogon pallidetarsata and by Macfie (1944) as
B. atrata
.
